siminsee 0.1.0
  • Reference

siminsee

The goal of siminsee is to simulate survival trial data with censoring under various scenarios using hospital and INSEE administrative data.

Installation

You can install the development version of siminsee like so:

# install.packages("usethis")
usethis::use_dev_package("siminsee")
library(siminsee)

Simulations

We use “nlisttrial” function to simulate different scenarios with parameters.

nlisttrial(scenario = 2, 
  nrepeat = c(1, 3),
  nbp = c(5, 4),
  lambda0 = rep(0.00175601, 2),
  HR = c(1, 0.7),
  tacc =  rep(60, 2),
  tfu =  rep(60, 2),
  lambda_pdv1 = rep(0.01, 2),
  lambda_pdv2 = rep(0.01, 2),
  t_pdv2 = rep(36, 2),
  HR_pdv = rep(1, 2),
  pinsee0 = rep(0.9, 2),
  pinsee1 = rep(0.9, 2),
  seed = 2023)
#> $dat
#> # A tibble: 17 × 25
#>    scenario nrepeat    id gr    time_accrual fu_theo delevt_true evt_true
#>       <int>   <int> <int> <fct>        <dbl>   <dbl>       <dbl>    <dbl>
#>  1        1       1     1 0               12     108       108          0
#>  2        1       1     2 1               24      96        56.3        1
#>  3        1       1     3 0               36      84        84          0
#>  4        1       1     4 1               48      72        72          0
#>  5        1       1     5 0               60      60        60          0
#>  6        2       1     1 0               15     105       105          0
#>  7        2       1     2 1               30      90        90          0
#>  8        2       1     3 0               45      75        75          0

#> 10        2       2     1 0               15     105       105          0

#> 12        2       2     3 0               45      75        75          0
#> 13        2       2     4 1               60      60        60          0
#> 14        2       3     1 0               15     105       105          0

Analyses

Comparison of estimation approach

We use the ‘resu_dat_1gr’ function to calculate percentages of patients with events, lost to follow-up, excluded alive or immortal according to the estimation approach for each repetition of each scenario of the simulated data.

sim <- nlisttrial(scenario = 6, 
  nrepeat = rep(1, 6),
  nbp = rep(5000, 6),
  lambda0 = c(rep(0.00175601, 3), rep(0.0085, 3)),
  HR = rep(1, 6),
  tacc = rep(60, 6),
  tfu = rep(60, 6),
  lambda_pdv1 = rep(0.01, 6),
  lambda_pdv2 = rep(0.01, 6),
  t_pdv2 = rep(36, 6),
  HR_pdv = rep(1, 6),
  pinsee0 = rep(c(0.8, 0.9, 0.99), 2),
  pinsee1 =rep(c(0.8, 0.9, 0.99), 2),
  seed = 2023)

resu_dat_1gr(sim)
#> $result
#> # A tibble: 6 × 13
#>   scenario nrepeat p_evt_true p_evt_hop p_pdv_hop p_exv_hop p_evt_hopinsee
#>      <int>   <int>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1        1       1      0.14     0.0944     0.557     0.349          0.130
#> 2        2       1      0.14     0.0944     0.557     0.349          0.134
#> 3        3       1      0.14     0.0944     0.557     0.349          0.139
#> 4        4       1      0.511    0.349      0.447     0.204          0.480
#> 5        5       1      0.511    0.349      0.447     0.204          0.495
#> 6        6       1      0.511    0.349      0.447     0.204          0.509
#> # ℹ 6 more variables: p_pdv_hopinsee <dbl>, p_exv_hopinsee <dbl>,
#> #   p_evt_hopinseeimp <dbl>, p_pdv_hopinseeimp <dbl>, p_exv_hopinseeimp <dbl>,
#> #   p_imm_hopinseeimp <dbl>
#> 
#> $parameters
#> # A tibble: 6 × 13
#>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2
#>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl>
#> 1        1       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01
#> 2        2       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01
#> 3        3       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01
#> 4        4       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01
#> 5        5       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01
#> 6        6       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01
#> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl>

We use the ‘ana_1gr’ function to perform Cox model analyses of the simulated data to compare the estimation approaches (hospital data, hospital data + INSEE and hospital data + INSEE + imputation). The function returns the Hazard Ratios comparing each estimation approaches with the estimation based on the true data for each scenario and repetition.

This function should be used when all patients are in the same group (‘HR’ in function trial should be equal to 1).

ana_mult_1gr(sim)
#> $result
#> # A tibble: 6 × 5
#>   scenario nrepeat HR_hop HR_hopinsee HR_hopinseeimp
#>      <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl>       <dbl>          <dbl>
#> 1        1       1  1.02         1.42          0.924
#> 2        2       1  1.02         1.47          0.954
#> 3        3       1  1.02         1.53          0.994
#> 4        4       1  0.994        1.28          0.923
#> 5        5       1  0.994        1.31          0.960
#> 6        6       1  0.994        1.34          0.996
#> 
#> $parameters
#> # A tibble: 6 × 13
#>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2
#>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl>
#> 1        1       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01
#> 2        2       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01
#> 3        3       1  5000    60    60 0.00176     1        0.01        0.01
#> 4        4       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01
#> 5        5       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01
#> 6        6       1  5000    60    60 0.0085      1        0.01        0.01
#> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl>
sim <- nlisttrial(scenario = 9, 
                  nrepeat = rep(1, 9),
                  nbp = rep(500, 9),
                  lambda0 = c(rep(0.001756009, 3), rep(0.008513760, 3), rep(0.02310490, 3)),
                  HR = rep(1, 9),
                  tacc = rep(60, 9),
                  tfu = rep(60, 9),
                  lambda_pdv1 = rep(c(0.01, 0.01, 0.02), 3),
                  lambda_pdv2 = rep(c(0.01, 0.02, 0.02), 3),
                  t_pdv2 = rep(36, 9),
                  HR_pdv = rep(1, 9),
                  pinsee0 = rep(0.9, 9),
                  pinsee1 =rep(0.9, 9),
                  seed = 2023)
graph_surv1gr(sim)

res <- ana_mult_1gr(sim)
graph_HR1gr_tt2(res)

Comparison of 2 groups

We use the ‘ana_mult_2gr’ function to perform Cox model analyses of the above simulated data to compare the 2 groups (for example treatment). The function returns the results of the analyses for the 4 estimation approaches (true data, hospital data, hospital data + INSEE and hospital data + INSEE + imputation) for each scenario and each repetition.

sim <- nlisttrial(scenario = 2,
                  nrepeat = rep(5, 2),
                   nbp = rep(2000, 2),
                   lambda0 = c(0.00175601,  0.0085),
                   HR = rep(0.7, 2),
                   tacc =  rep(60, 2),
                   tfu =   rep(60, 2),
                   lambda_pdv1 = c(0.01, 0.01),
                   lambda_pdv2 = c(0.01,0.02),
                   t_pdv2 = rep(36,2),
                   HR_pdv = c(1,1.1),
                   pinsee0 = rep(0.9, 2),
                   pinsee1 = rep(0.9, 2),
                  seed = 2023)
ana_mult_2gr(sim)
#> $result
#> # A tibble: 10 × 30
#>    scenario nrepeat log_HR_true HR_true waldtest_true pval_test_true
#>       <dbl>   <dbl>       <dbl>   <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl>
#>  1        1       1      -0.285   0.752          4.73       2.96e- 2
#>  2        1       2      -0.311   0.733          5.77       1.63e- 2
#>  3        1       3      -0.428   0.651         11.7        6.34e- 4
#>  4        1       4      -0.231   0.794          3.40       6.51e- 2
#>  5        1       5      -0.398   0.672          8.48       3.60e- 3
#>  6        2       1      -0.323   0.724         22.8        1.83e- 6
#>  7        2       2      -0.280   0.756         17.6        2.68e- 5
#>  8        2       3      -0.385   0.680         35.2        2.90e- 9
#>  9        2       4      -0.334   0.716         26.5        2.63e- 7
#> 10        2       5      -0.453   0.636         46.3        1.03e-11
#> # ℹ 24 more variables: success_uni_cox_true <dbl>, failure_cox_true <dbl>,
#> #   success_bi_cox_true_true <dbl>, log_HR_hop <dbl>, HR_hop <dbl>,
#> #   waldtest_hop <dbl>, pval_test_hop <dbl>, success_uni_cox_hop <dbl>,
#> #   failure_cox_hop <dbl>, success_bi_cox_true_hop <dbl>,
#> #   log_HR_hopinsee <dbl>, HR_hopinsee <dbl>, waldtest_hopinsee <dbl>,
#> #   pval_test_hopinsee <dbl>, success_uni_cox_hopinsee <dbl>,
#> #   failure_cox_hopinsee <dbl>, success_bi_cox_true_hopinsee <dbl>, …
#> 
#> $parameters
#> # A tibble: 2 × 13
#>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2
#>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl>
#> 1        1       5  2000    60    60 0.00176   0.7        0.01        0.01
#> 2        2       5  2000    60    60 0.0085    0.7        0.01        0.02
#> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl>

We use ‘mean_coeff_ana_2gr’ function to have mean estimations of coefficients of the Cox modeling over repetitions for each scenario.

res <- ana_mult_2gr(sim) 
mean_coeff_ana_2gr(res)
#> $result
#> # A tibble: 2 × 28
#>   scenario nrepeat exp_m_log_HR_true m_log_HR_true p_suc_uni_true p_suc_bi_true
#>      <dbl>   <dbl>             <dbl>         <dbl>          <dbl>         <dbl>
#> 1        1       5             0.718        -0.331            0.8             0
#> 2        2       5             0.701        -0.355            1               0
#> # ℹ 22 more variables: p_fail_true <dbl>, exp_m_log_HR_hop <dbl>,
#> #   m_log_HR_hop <dbl>, biais_abs_hop <dbl>, biais_rel_hop <dbl>,
#> #   p_suc_uni_hop <dbl>, p_suc_bi_hop <dbl>, p_fail_hop <dbl>,
#> #   exp_m_log_HR_hopinsee <dbl>, m_log_HR_hopinsee <dbl>,
#> #   biais_abs_hopinsee <dbl>, biais_rel_hopinsee <dbl>,
#> #   p_suc_uni_hopinsee <dbl>, p_suc_bi_hopinsee <dbl>, p_fail_hopinsee <dbl>,
#> #   exp_m_log_HR_hopinseeimp <dbl>, m_log_HR_hopinseeimp <dbl>, …
#> 
#> $parameters
#> # A tibble: 2 × 13
#>   scenario nrepeat   nbp  tacc   tfu lambda0    HR lambda_pdv1 lambda_pdv2
#>      <int>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>       <dbl>       <dbl>
#> 1        1       5  2000    60    60 0.00176   0.7        0.01        0.01
#> 2        2       5  2000    60    60 0.0085    0.7        0.01        0.02
#> # ℹ 4 more variables: t_pdv2 <dbl>, HR_pdv <dbl>, pinsee0 <dbl>, pinsee1 <dbl>
mean_res <- mean_coeff_ana_2gr(res) 
graph_biais_grp_tt2(mean_res)

graph_beta_grp_tt2(mean_res)

graph_alpha_grp_tt2(mean_res)
